Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story:
The store is packed, the line winding past the candy racks, and I’m at the register, scanning items as quickly as I can. My phone buzzes in my pocket—a message from Jamie. I glance at the screen and my heart sinks. “Why would you say that? I thought we were closer than that.” I realize my last text must have come off cold, and now Jamie’s hurt. I know I should call right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grows. That’s what a good friend would do—communicate, fix it, not let it fester.

But right in front of me, a customer is frowning, arms crossed, complaining about a missing discount. The line behind her is restless, and I can feel the pressure to stay calm, smile, and keep things moving. My manager is watching from the end of the aisle. I’m supposed to be the friendly, unflappable cashier, even when customers are upset.

My phone vibrates again. I can’t ignore Jamie, but I can’t abandon my post either. My chest tightens as I weigh the expectations—be a good friend, be a good employee. I grip the scanner, torn, wishing I could be in two places at once.
